title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals, including intentional releases. The Act defines hazardous agents as dangerous biological agents and chemicals, with specific criteria for what constitutes a dangerous biological agent. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act defines dangerous biological agents as those listed in the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 and not exempted from regulations. It also includes dangerous chemicals listed by the Secretary in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act identifies substances known to cause death or serious health effects, including those listed under section 112(r)(3) of the Act. Protocols are developed for each hazardous agent, with specific provisions unless the agent has no unique characteristics relevant to a public health emergency response. Priorities and timeframes are set within 45 days for response protocols. The Secretary must establish priorities for hazardous agents within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Protocols for the highest priority agent must be developed promptly, with a goal of completion within 45 days. The provisions of each protocol must ensure uniform application in public health emergencies involving the hazardous agent. The Secretary must establish priorities for hazardous agents and develop protocols promptly to ensure uniform application in public health emergencies. The protocols include coordinating with emergency response personnel, providing information to individuals present at the emergency site, testing and treating affected individuals, decontaminating sites, and responding differently based on the nature of the hazardous agent release. Additionally, the Secretary shall periodically review the protocols. The Secretary will periodically review and revise protocols for hazardous agents as needed. Development exemptions may be granted if existing protocols meet requirements. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 may be necessary in addition to other authorizations available for the same purpose.
